advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert price list:<br><br> 16K RAM: <b>$399</b> (kit) <b>$459</b> (assembled)<br> Parity option: <b>$39</b> (kit) <b>$59</b> (assembled)<br> Floating point board: <b>$259</b> (kit) <b>$359</b> (assembled)<br> Z80 board: <b>$199</b> (kit) <b>$259</b> (assembled)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">No one knows better than Microsoft how to increase your TRS-80 BASIC's power. Microsoft created the TRS-80 Level ll and Disk BASIC plus the industry standard Microsoft BASIC...<br><br> ...Microsoft Level lll BASIC is an enhancement to the Level ll. It contains all Disk BASIC features not already in Level ll and it adds six new Level lll exclusives...<br> ...Advanced graphics is Level lll's most exciting addition to the TRS-80 - and it's exclusive. Draw a line, outline or solid box by specifying just two points, then save it and put it back with BASIC statement. You'll find yourself writing more programs with charts, graphs and even animation...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to François Houste and <a href="http://www.phijvmi.com" target="_blank">www.phijvmi.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1991)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This japanese advert indicates that there were at least 3 different models sold...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983<br><br> Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The new Epson QX-10 is unlike any personal computer you've never seen. It's a computer for people who don't have the time to learn computer; a computer you can be using within minutes...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC.1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This french brochure presented games from #1 to #43</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Thank you boss !" <br><br> The ad incite employees to ask their boss to buy these Apricot systems...clever.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tim_K for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Welcome in the world of the "clean"-computers"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SECOND 6502</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Second Processor option features, in a separate case, a 3 MHz 6502 processor and 64 KB of RAM. It was connected to the BBC system through the Tube channel. The BBC RAM was then used as video RAM, so the full memory area of the Second Processor was available for user programs.<br> Two ROMs was also delivered. The first one holded a new BASIC version called HI-BASIC that made full use of the new memory configuration. The other updated disc or Econet filling system.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8BS.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"After the compliments made to the Amstrad CPC-464, what could be added ?"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEMOTECH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The memory tool''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://pcenginefx.com" target="_blank">PC-EngineFX.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT FROM NEW ZEALAND</strong></font><br><blockquote>In November 1976, the assembled basic version cost A$931, the unassembled version cost A$599.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: Single or dual cassette tape drives
computer.description:
Software for this system includes the debugger (in ROM), a BASIC interpreter, a FORTRAN compiler and a linker. The ROM debugger features interactive translation of assembly language mnemonics, tape, disk and printer commands and multiple breakpoints.
The system was available in two configurations : the DEC68 DT (pictured above) which includes a FDD, and the DEC68 C which fits into a smaller case without the FDD. It was priced from $2000.
computer.media: Single or dual cassette tape drives
computer.name: DE 68DT
computer.text: 20 characters alphanumeric display + 40 character per line built-in impact printer
